Squizzy:

"SO your making up for the damaged caused by other transformers. 
Ahhh, I see. Truely noble indeed. I will assist you in this as best 
as I can."  She thought that this was the biggest line of slag she 
ever heard, but for now, she would play along.



-- In nbwrpg@egroups.com, "CYBERWOLF4" <cyberwolf4@p...> wrote:
> In a way Squizzy was right, but not entirely. "In the best of my 
knowledge,
> whenever translife encounters a planet one of two things happen, 
either the
> translife changes the world, or the world destroys the translife." 
She
> thought back looking for examples. the best she could find was the 
example
> of her former planet. "Where I came from Insecticons overran most 
of the
> system, a scientist, His name I can't remember I was too young, saw 
that the
> planets not effected were planets with a large amount of avian 
life. The
> scientist gathered DNA samples and injected them into the translife 
on my
> old planet. They destroyed the insecticons and saved the planet 
from being a
> buffet." She didn't want to give up to much information about her 
origin so
> she turned back to the Dna readouts.
> 
> "I hope to save and restore other planets that have suffered at 
translife
> hands, I feel we owe the universe that much for the damage done in 
the great
> wars." She studied the samples more closely "Perhaps these two 
animals
> aren't the best example but it's just a sample for Zardus to see."
> 
> 
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: <logomorph@h...>
> To: <nbwrpg@egroups.com>
> Sent: Tuesday, October 17, 2000 6:46 AM
> Subject: Re: To make a long story short (To late) Part 2
> 
> 
> > Squizzy::
> >
> > She nodded.  She didn't know what this bot was up to, but the 
whole
> > idea wasn't all that bad. "So your not going to destroy the
> > ecosystem, mearly help it along so both bot and naute can 
coexist?"
> > She smiled. "I had never seen that done before, but if it is
> > possable, that nature and bot can exist in harmony like that, I'd 
be
> > glad to help try."
> >
> > She smiled and showed her willingness to help.  But her mind was
> > trying to figure out what this bot was really up to.  This bot 
wasn't
> > what she appeared to be.  There was something that LadyHawk was
> > hiding.   But she couldn't quite figure it out.  She wondered why
> > this bot, who knew all this knowledge was having her do most of 
the
> > work? Then it came to her, LadyHawk didn't know it all.  But 
then, if
> > she didn't know, why pretend to know.  To save her tail feathers?
> > Most llikely.  But for now, Squizzy would play along and find out 
all
> > she could.
> >
> >
> > --- In nbwrpg@egroups.com, "CYBERWOLF4" <cyberwolf4@p...> wrote:
> > > Lady Hawk was startled by the revelation. She tried to remain
> > collected.
> > > "Are we not disrupting this planets growth just by being here?"
> > Lady Hawk
> > > knew the results every time technology was introduced into an
> > ecosystem. "My
> > > hopes aren't to upset the natural balance but to create a middle
> > ground
> > > between what we are and what the planet could be." It was an
> > argument her
> > > father had used hundreds of times but every time the warmongers
> > would turn
> > > the argument around and throw it in his face.
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
